title: (Trying to) Revive a Mac SE/30
description: Compact Macs from the 80s and 90s suffer from a common problem that results in scrambled video. But the common solution sometimes isn't enough to fix it.  "Simasimac" information:  Classic Mac schematics:   -----------------------------------------------------------------------------  Please consider supporting my work on Patreon:   Follow me on Twitter and Instagram! @thisdoesnotcomp  -----------------------------------------------------------------------------  Music: "Now or Never (You and Me)" by Dan Mason ( Additional music by Epidemic Sound ( Intro music by BoxCat Games (
transcript: Hey everyone, it's Colin. How's it going? This old Mac doesn't want a boot. Question is, can I get it up and running again? I was given a Macintosh SE/30 by my friends over at Free Geek Twin Cities. It's a favorite among classic Mac collectors, but it also suffers from a common problem. Instead of booting up, It just displays this black and white mosaic pattern. Like with a lot of vintage electronics, bad electrolytic capacitors are often the culprit. So I took the Mac apart to see if replacing them would bring it back to life. Well shit! So yeah, that... that didn't fix it. Which is frustrating. At the same time, there was always a chance of that being the case. This particular problem, well, it effect pretty much the entire line of black and white compact Macs and it's so prevalent that it even has a name. Reportedly, a group of Japanese compact Mac enthusiasts came up with the term "Simasimac" to describe this exact scenario. What sucks is that there's no single clear-cut solution to fix it. Obviously, bad capacitors on the motherboard are going to be a common cause because well, technology from the 80s and 90s, bad caps were a thing. We're going to see more and more of it as more and more people get into retro technology and want to restore it. But that's not the only cause for this particular problem. Now, in my case, It seemed like it was worth a shot because the caps had failed. I saw plenty of electrolyte residue on the motherboard and so it's a good first step to do for troubleshooting anyway. What I didn't see on the motherboard though, when I was working on it was any obvious signs of damage. I mean, none of the solder traces looked like they had corroded, didn't see any damage to the pins of any components. I went through and cleaned the board actually a couple of times, once on-camera and once off, again with a toothbrush and a whole lot more IPA. Nothing obviously wrong with the board, based on visual inspection, and that's where this particular problem starts to get kind of nasty when it comes to solving it because once you've tried the obvious step of replacing the caps, well, It's a rabbit hole that you end up going down to try and figure out exactly what else could be wrong. And it could be many different things, I've read reports of people trying to restore these boards Especially in the SE/30, and having to go back to the original motherboard schematics and test pretty much everything point-to-point to see if there's any sort of break and a solder joint somewhere, figure out what component may be failing or half-failing. And not only is that time-consuming, but sometimes it takes special knowledge The diagrams and schematics for circuit boards like this are great at telling you how everything is hooked up, but they don't really tell you how it works necessarily. There's still a whole bunch of knowledge as to what exactly happens when you power the computer on like what components talk to each other and what are they expecting to see? That's just knowledge that I don't have so, it may come down to where I need to reach out to someone else who has more experience fixing these problems to try to figure out what may be going on with this board. That said, I'm still holding out hope because that board does look like it's in good shape. I also looked at some of the other components in the system thinking "Well maybe there's an external factor involved" and that doesn't really seem to be the case. The analog board and power supply, they have capacitors on their boards as well but they all look to be in really good shape. No obvious signs of leaking or anything like that and furthermore, when this "Simasimac" problem tends to occur, usually doesn't implicate either the analog board or the power supply. It'd be a different set of symptoms if that was what was going on. So, I'm pretty sure it's just limited to the motherboard in this scenario question is, what's it going to take to fix? Well, that is something we will find out in due time. I'm sure I'll revisit this topic, but for now at least, well, I just have a whole lot more research and tinkering to do. Anyway, if you liked the video, I would appreciate a thumbs up. Be sure to subscribe. You can follow me on Twitter and Instagram @ThisDoesNotComp and as always, thanks for watching.
